title: Canine Anaphylaxis Rapid Response
summary: Immediate ABC stabilization, epinephrine dosing, antihistamines, and shock fluid boluses.
actions: Assess airway/breathing; provide oxygen and prepare for intubation if stridor or swelling progresses.
Epinephrine 0.01 mg/kg IM or IV for collapse; repeat every 3-5 minutes as needed.
Give isotonic crystalloids 20 mL/kg IV bolus; reassess perfusion and repeat up to 3 times for shock.
Diphenhydramine 1 mg/kg IM; add H2 blocker and corticosteroid for refractory signs.
Monitor ECG, blood pressure, SpO2, and temperature; be prepared for biphasic reactions.

title: Feline Heatstroke Stabilization
summary: Rapid cooling, fluid resuscitation, and coagulopathy monitoring for heat stress cases.
actions: Stop external heat, move to shaded/air-conditioned area, and start fan-assisted evaporative cooling.
Cool IV crystalloids 10-20 mL/kg over 15-30 minutes if hypoperfused; avoid overcooling (<39°C).
Check glucose, electrolytes, and lactate; treat hypoglycemia promptly and monitor for rhabdomyolysis.
Avoid antipyretics (ineffective); use active cooling and recheck rectal temperature every 5 minutes.
Assess for DIC with coagulation panel; consider plasma if bleeding or prolonged clotting times.

title: Dog Maintenance Fluid Calculator
summary: Compute maintenance and deficit replacement with pump or drip sets.
actions: Baseline maintenance: 60 mL/kg/day; adjust for fever (add 10% per °C above normal) and polyuria.
Deficit: weight (kg) × % dehydration × 1000 = mL to replace over 12-24 hours.
If using drip set: macro 15 gtt/mL, micro 60 gtt/mL; compute drops/min from mL/hr × gtt factor / 60.
Avoid hypotonic fluids if sodium <135 mmol/L; monitor electrolytes every 6-12 hours in hospitalized patients.
Link plan to ongoing losses (vomiting/diarrhea) and reassess perfusion every 2 hours during correction.

title: Feline Pain Control with NSAIDs
summary: Safe NSAID selection and monitoring checkpoints for cats.
actions: Use lowest effective dose; avoid concurrent corticosteroids or other NSAIDs to reduce GI and renal risk.
Screen for dehydration, CKD, and hepatic disease; postpone NSAID use if unstable perfusion.
Provide gastroprotectants when risk factors for ulceration are present; recheck creatinine within 3-5 days.
Educate clients on accurate dosing, avoiding OTC human NSAIDs, and watching for anorexia/vomiting.

title: Canine CBC Quick Reference
summary: Common canine CBC intervals with critical value reminders.
actions: PCV 37-55%; critical <20% or >60% depending on clinical context.
Platelets 200-500k/µL; investigate <50k/µL urgently for risk of bleeding.
WBC 6-17 ×10^3/µL; watch for toxic change or left shift signaling sepsis.
Pair CBC trends with hydration assessment; hemoconcentration can mask anemia in dehydrated patients.
